column1: What is the name of the course?

column2: TBD (in-person)

column1: What are the specific course objectives?
column2: To cover core methods in educational data mining, teach execution in standard software, understand limitations, and know when and why to use these methods.

column1: What are the overall expectations from students?
column2: Watch asynchronous videos, engage with content, complete assignments, and provide feedback on peers' work.

column1: Where are the course readings?
column2: Most readings are on the course schedule webpage (https://www.upenn.edu/learninganalytics/ryanbaker/EDM2023/index.html); other readings may be provided in class.

column1: What additional materials does this course use?
column2: Most readings are on the course schedule webpage (https://www.upenn.edu/learninganalytics/ryanbaker/EDM2023/index.html); other readings may be provided in class.

column1: What is the course website?
column2: Please refer to: https://www.upenn.edu/learninganalytics/ryanbaker/EDM2023/index.html

column1: What is the course discussion forum?
column2: http://educ6191-f23.jeepytee.net/

column1: Is there a required text? If so, what is it?
column2: Yes, "Big Data and Education, 7th edition" by R.S. Baker (available at: https://www.upenn.edu/learninganalytics/MOOT/bigdataeducation.html)

column1: What textbook is being used in this course?
column2: "Big Data and Education, 7th edition" by R.S. Baker (available at: https://www.upenn.edu/learninganalytics/MOOT/bigdataeducation.html)

column1: Important dates (due dates, assignments, etc.)?
column2: For detailed information about the assignments, please visit the course webpage https://www.upenn.edu/learninganalytics/ryanbaker/EDM2023/index.html

column1: What is the prerequisite of this course?
column2: Python, EDUC7667, or instructor permission. Proficiency in Python is essential

column1: What is a basic assignment?
column2: Practice questions on Assistment platform. For any setup inquiries, please contact the TAs.

column1: When will I find the basic assignments?
column2: Basic assignments are on the ASSISTments platform. You can use Google Classroom or ASSISTments directly.

column1: What are basic assignments like?
column2: Basic assignments involve data mining with instant feedback and context-sensitive hints.

column1: What happens if I make a mistake in the basic assignment?
column2: Making errors in the basic assignment has no penalties, regardless of what the system says.

column1: What happens if I use hints in the basic assignment?
column2: Requesting hints in the basic assignment incurs no penalties, unless you game the system.

column1: How many hints can I use in the basic assignment?
column2: You can use all the hints without penalties, unless you game the system.

column1: How will you know if I game the system?
column2: The system has a built-in detector to automatically detect instances of gaming the system.

column1: Can I get credit if I used all the hints for a question?
column2: Yes, there are no penalties for requesting hints, regardless of what the system says, unless you game the system.

column1: Where can I view my grade after completing assignments?
column2: If you complete the assignment in time, you will receive full credit.

column1: What should I do after finishing each creative assignment?
column2: After submitting your own creative assignment, post meaningfully on four other students' creative assignments. Either section is fine.

column1: What are the expectations for creative assignment?
column2: Creative assignments focus on personal discovery and learning from text and video resources, not flawless execution.

column1: What does it mean to post on other students' assignments?
column2: After submitting your own creative assignment, post meaningfully on four other students' creative assignments. Either section is fine.

column1: Why do I need to post on other students' assignments?
column2: Posting on others' assignments allows you to explore alternative problem-solving approaches and benefits both you and your classmates.

column1: How many students' assignments do I need to post on?
column2: After submitting your own creative assignment, post meaningfully on four other students' creative assignments. Either section is fine.

column1: Can I discuss my approach with a friend for the assignment?
column2: Yes! You can discuss different approaches, but not share step-by-step solutions.

column1: Can I do the assignment with a classmate but write separately?
column2: No, assignments are individual, but discussing readings or technical details on the forum is allowed.

column1: Can I discuss readings or technical details on the forum?
column2: Yes! You can discuss readings and technical details with your classmates as long as you don't share step-by-step solutions.

column1: Can I ask my friend a UI question about ASSISTments?
column2: Yes.

column1: What can I discuss with my classmates?
column2: You can discuss anything except sharing step-by-step solutions to assignments.

column1: Can I do homework with friends together?
column2: No, assignments are individual, but discussing readings or technical details on the forum is allowed.

column1: What is the collaboration policy in class?
column2: All assignments are individual. You must submit your own work, but discussing readings or technical details on the forum is allowed.

column1: Can I get inspiration from my classmates' assignment posts?
column2: Not recommended, but it's not considered an ethical violation.

column1: Can I copy my classmates' code for any assignment?
column2: No.

column1: Can I copy my classmates' modified dataset for any assignment?
column2: No.

column1: Can we work in groups for the assignments?
column2: No, all assignments are individual, but discussing readings or technical details on the forum is allowed.

column1: How can I get in touch with Ryan?
column2: You can post to the forum, come to office hours, or set up a virtual meeting with penn.learninganalytics@gmail.com or rybaker@upenn.edu.

column1: Will you accommodate students?
column2: Ryan tries to accommodate every student. You can talk to him during office hours or email the professor or TAs to set up a meeting.

column1: I am worried about my coding skills, what should I do?
column2: Come talk to us during office hours or email the professor or TAs to set up a meeting. Ryan tries to find a way to accommodate every student.

column1: I have limited programming background in computer science, what should I do?
column2: Come talk to us during office hours or email the professor or TAs to set up a meeting. Ryan tries to find a way to accommodate every student.

column1: What should I do if I have a technical question or a question of general interest for the class?
column2: You are highly recommended to post it on the discussion forum.

column1: What happens if I submit my assignment after the deadline?
column2: Please contact the professor and explain why your assignment is/will be late.

column1: What is the policy for late assignments?
column2: The professor intends to be more flexible than usual on extensions, but please contact the professor and explain why your assignment is/will be late.

column1: What is a creative assignment?
column2: In creative assignments, you will be given a prompt and expected to use all the knowledge learned from basic assignments to complete the project independently.

column1: How many assignments are required?
column2: Six basic assignments and three creative assignments.

column1: How many basic assignments are required?
column2: Please choose 6 out of 8 to complete: 3 from the first 4 (e.g. Basic Homework 1-4) and 3 from the second 4 (e.g. Basic Homework 5-8)

column1: Where do I submit the assignments?
column2: Please submit all assignments on the discussion forum: http://educ.jeepytee.net/

column1: How many creative assignments are required?
column2: Please choose 3 out of 4 assigned creative homework.

column1: What happens if I do more basic assignments?
column2: Extra assignments will receive feedback but not be graded or replace higher graded ones.

column1: What happens if I do more creative assignments?
column2: Extra assignments will receive feedback but not be graded or replace higher graded ones.

column1: What is the attendance policy for the course?
column2: Attendance is not mandatory, but active participation is encouraged for a better learning experience.

column1: What is the expected classroom behavior?
column2: Participate actively by asking questions and contributing comments during in-person classes.

column1: What is required asynchronous activities?
column2: Complete creative assignments and provide substantive comments on at least four other students' submissions within five days to count towards your grade.

column1: What are the grading criteria?
column2: 6 of 8 Basic Assignments (up to 36%), 3 of 4 Creative Assignments (up to 39%), Asynchronous participation (up to 24%), and 1 bonus point.

column1: When is the midterm?
column2: No, there are no exams in this course.

column1: When is the final exam?
column2: No, there are no exams in this course.

column1: Is there a tentative exam schedule?
column2: No, there are no exams in this course.

column1: What is the bonus for creative assignments?
column2: The best hand-in for each creative assignment receives a special bonus of 20%.

column1: Can AI be used for homework assistance?
column2: Yes, you can use any of the foundation models, but please acknowledge their use in your hand-ins.

column1: Can I get an extension for the assignments?
column2: Contact the professor for extensions, but please be reasonable.

column1: What is the course mask policy?
column2: Please wear a mask during class if possible.

column1: What is the policy on academic dishonesty?
column2: Plagiarism or improper citation is not tolerated and follows the university's policy on academic dishonesty.

column1: Is there a disability accommodation statement?
column2: Please email Ryan to set up a meeting so we can best accommodate you.

column1: Is there a makeup policy for missed exams or assignments?
column2: Extensions will be given as needed within reasonable circumstances.

column1: Are there any opportunities of earning extra credit?
column2: The best hand-in for each creative assignment receives a special bonus of 20%. There are no other extra credit opportunities.

column1: Is there a group project?
column2: No, there is no group project in this course.

column1: When are assignments made available?
column2: Assignments for the course are accessible from the start and can be accessed through the course webpage: https://www.upenn.edu/learninganalytics/ryanbaker/EDM2023/index.html

column1: Do we have a class on labor day?
column2: No, there's no class on Labor Day on September 4, 2023. Please refer to the academic calendar - https://almanac.upenn.edu/penn-academic-calendar

column1: What is the deadline to drop this course?
column2: Drop period for courses ends on October 9. Please refer to the academic calendar - https://almanac.upenn.edu/penn-academic-calendar

column1: When is the fall break?
column2: The fall break is from October 12-15. Please refer to the academic calendar - https://almanac.upenn.edu/penn-academic-calendar

column1: What is Jeepytee?
column2: Jeepytee is a LLM-powered TA. It is not just basic GPT-4; we have done some pre-training.

column1: What can Jeepytee do?
column2: Jeepytee will answer some of your questions when Ryan and the TAs aren't available.

column1: I will miss the next class. What should I do?

column1: If I missed the class, will I lose my participation grade?

column1: Do I need to know programming to take this class?

column2: No, we will not be teaching Python in class. However, you will have the opportunity to learn and practice it through basic assignments.

column1: Do I need to know statistics to take this class?
column2: This is not a statistics class but EDM methods will be compared to statistics throughout the class. Statistics background is recommended but not required.
